characters.description: A pair of enormous, blue eyes behind yellow spectacles overlooking the valley of ashes. They represent a faded sign and perhaps a forgotten moral presence.
A wealthy and assertive man having an affair. He brings the narrator to meet his mistress and displays a possessive and sometimes violent nature.
An unnamed character who is taken to meet Tom Buchanan's mistress and observes the unfolding events. He seems somewhat passive and judgmental.
A spiritless and anaemic garage owner, seemingly unaware of his wife's affair. He is desperate to buy a car from Tom and appears downtrodden.
Tom Buchanan's mistress, a woman in her middle thirties with a strong vitality. She is married to George Wilson but desires a more luxurious life.
A grey, scrawny child seen setting torpedoes on the railroad track. The child adds to the desolate atmosphere of the valley of ashes.
An old man selling puppies from a basket. He is encountered by Tom, Myrtle and the narrator where Myrtle purchases a dog from him.
Myrtle Wilson's sister, a slender and worldly girl with red hair. She is visiting Myrtle and is very opinionated.
A pale and feminine photographer from the apartment below. He is in the "artistic game" and took a photograph of Myrtle's mother.
Shrill, languid, handsome, and horrible, she is married to Mr. McKee. She proudly states that her husband has photographed her a hundred and twenty-seven times since they had been married.
A reluctant worker who is sent to get items for the dog. He is not very enthusiastic about his job.
A worker who is sent out to buy sandwiches. He is part of the lower orders.
